form.longName: PhenX PX120202 - Anxiety Disorders Screener Adult
form.preferredDefinition: This protocol is divided into two separate parts. The first part contains the subsections of the Composite International Diagnostic Interview - Short Form (CIDI-SF) that screen for the presence or absence of generalized anxiety disorder, specific phobia, social phobia, agoraphobia and panic attack. The second part contains specific questions from the Symptom Check List 90 (SCL-90) that provide a more quantitative measure of anxiety symptom severity.

module.longName: Part I: Anxiety Screener from the Composite International Diagnostic Interview - Short Form
module.preferredDefinition: Part I: Anxiety Screener from the Composite International Diagnostic Interview - Short Form

question.questionText: Have you ever had a period lasting one month or longer when most of the time you felt worried, tense, or anxious? (pxt120202_gad_worried_two_weeks)
People differ a lot in how much they worry about things. Did you ever have a time when you worried a lot more than most people would in your situation? (pxt120202_gad_worried_more_than_others)
What is the longest period of time that this kind of worrying has ever continued? (Years) (pxt120202_gad_longest_time_worried_years)
What is the longest period of time that this kind of worrying has ever continued? (Months) (pxt120202_gad_longest_time_worried_months)
What is the longest period of time that this kind of worrying has ever continued? (pxt120202_gad_longest_time_worried_always)

validValue.meaningText: all of my life/as long as I can remember
validValue.description: all of my life/as long as I can remember

question.questionText: Please think of the period in your life when you have felt worried, tense, anxious, or more worried than most people would in your situation. This could be in the past, or it could be continuing now. (inst1_0220202)
During that period, was your worry stronger than in other people? (pxt120202_gad_longest_period_stronger_worry)
Did you worry most days? (pxt120202_gad_worry_most_days)
Did you usually worry about one particular thing, such as your job security or the failing health of a loved one, or more than one thing? (pxt120202_gad_worry_one_particular_thing)
Did you find it difficult to stop worrying? (pxt120202_gad_difficult_stop_worry)
Did you ever have different worries on your mind at the same time? (pxt120202_gad_different_worries_same_time)
How often was your worry so strong that you couldn't put it out of your mind no matter how hard you tried? (pxt120202_gad_worry_constantly_on_mind)
How often did you find it difficult to control your worry? (pxt120202_gad_difficult_control_worry)
When you were worried or anxious, were you also: Restless? (pxt120202_gad_also_restless)
When you were worried or anxious, were you also: Keyed up or on edge? (pxt120202_gad_also_on_edge)
When you were worried or anxious, were you also: Easily tired? (pxt120202_gad_also_easily_tired)
When you were worried or anxious, were you also: Having difficulty keeping your mind on what you were doing? (pxt120202_gad_also_difficulty_concentrating)
When you were worried or anxious, were you also: More irritable than usual? (pxt120202_gad_also_irritable)
When you were worried or anxious, were you also: Having tense, sore, or aching muscles? (pxt120202_gad_also_tense)
When you were worried or anxious, were you also: Often having trouble falling or staying asleep? (pxt120202_gad_also_trouble_sleeping)
Did you ever tell a professional about these problems (medical doctor, psychologist, social worker, counselor, nurse, clergy, or other helping professional)? (pxt120202_gad_tell_professional)
Did you take medication or use drugs or alcohol more than once for the worry or the problems it was causing? (pxt120202_gad_take_medication)
How much did the worry or anxiety interfere with your life or activities? (pxt120202_gad_interfere_activities)

instruction.text: 14. The next questions are about things that make some people so afraid that they avoid them, even when there is no real danger. Do you have an unreasonably strong fear or avoid any of the following things:

question.questionText: 14. The next questions are about things that make some people so afraid that they avoid them, even when there is no real danger. Do you have an unreasonably strong fear or avoid any of the following things: (inst14_0120202)
14a. Heights, storms, thunder, lightning, or being in still water, like a swimming pool or lakes? (pxt120202_specific_water)
14b. Being in a closed space like a cave, tunnel, elevator, or airplane? (pxt120202_specific_enclosed_space)
14c. Snakes, birds, rats, bugs, or other animals? (pxt120202_specific_animals)
14d. Seeing blood, getting a shot or injection, seeing a dentist, or going to a hospital? (pxt120202_specific_blood)
Please think of the situations that you fear such as 14a. Heights, storms, thunder, lightning, or being in still water, like a swimming pool or lakes. (inst14a_120202)
15. How often do you get upset when you are in that situation? (pxt120202_specific_how_often_upset)

validValue.meaningText: Only one or two times ever
validValue.description: Only one or two times ever

question.questionText: 16. How long have you had any of these fears? (specific_how_long_had_fears)
17. How long have you had any of these fears? (specific_how_long_had_fears_specifymonths)
18. How much have any of these fears ever interfered with your life or activities? (pxt120202_specific_interfere_activities)
19. Have you ever been very upset with yourself for having any of these fears? (pxt120202_specific_upset_with_self)
20. Is your fear unreasonable that is, much stronger than it should be? (pxt120202_specific_fear_unreasonable)
21. Is your fear much stronger than in other people? (specific_fear_stronger_than_others)
Please think of the situations that you fear such as: 14b. Being in a closed space like a cave, tunnel, elevator, or airplane: (binst_120202)
15. How often do you get upset when you are in that situation? (pxt120202_specific_ho2_a1f)

validValue.meaningText: Only one or two times ever
validValue.description: Only one or two times ever

21. Here's another list of situations that can cause unreasonably strong fears. They involve doing things in front of other people or being the center of attention. Do you have an unreasonably strong fear or avoid any of the following situations: (inst_120202)
21a. Giving a speech or speaking in public? (pxt120202_social_speech)
21b. Eating or drinking where someone could watch you? (pxt120202_social_public_drinking)
21c. Talking to people because you might have nothing to say or might sound foolish? (pxt120202_social_sound_foolish)
21d. Writing while someone watches? (pxt120202_social_writing)
21e. Taking part or speaking in a meeting or class? (pxt120202_social_speaking_class_meeting)
21f. Going to a party or other social outing? (pxt120202_social_party)
Please think only of the situation(s) that cause you unreasonably strong fears such as 21a. Giving a speech or speaking in public: (ainst120202)
22. How often do you get very upset when you are in this situation? (pxt120202_social_how_often_upset)

validValue.meaningText: Only one or two times ever
validValue.description: Only one or two times ever

23. How long have you had any of these fears? (pxt120202_social_how_long_hadfears_months)

instruction.text: 28. Here's a final list of situations that can cause unreasonably strong fears. Do you have an unreasonably strong fear for or avoid any of the following:

question.questionText: 28. Here's a final list of situations that can cause unreasonably strong fears. Do you have an unreasonably strong fear for or avoid any of the following: (inst28_120202)
28a. Being in a crowd or standing in line? (pxt120202_agoraphobia_crowd)
28b. Being away from home alone? (pxt120202_agoraphobia_away_from_home)
28c. Traveling alone? (pxt120202_agoraphobia_travelling_alone)
28d. Traveling in a bus, train, or car? (pxt120202_agoraphobia_bus_car_train)
28e. Being in a public place like a department store? (pxt120202_agoraphobia_public_place)
Please think only of the situation(s) that cause you to have unreasonably strong fears, such as 28a. Being in a crowd or standing in line: (inst28a_120202)
29. How often do you get very upset in the situation? (pxt120202_agoraphobia_how_often_upset)

validValue.meaningText: Only one or two times ever
validValue.description: Only one or two times ever

question.questionText: 30. How long have you had any of these fears? (pxt120202_agoraphobia_how_long_had_fears)
30. How long have you had any of these fears? (pxt120202_agoraphobia_howlong_had_fears_months)
31. Were you ever afraid that you might faint, lose control, or embarrass yourself in other ways? (pxt120202_agoraphobia_faint_embarrass)
32. Do you worry that you might be trapped without any way to escape? (pxt120202_agoraphobia2_f16)
33. Do you worry that help might not be available if you needed it? (pxt120202_agoraphobia_no_help)
34.How much did any of these fears ever interfere with your life or activities? (pxt120202_agoraphobia_interfere_with_activities)

question.questionText: 30. How long have you had any of these fears? (pxt120202_agoraphobia2_c25)
30. How long have you had any of these fears? (pxt120202_agoraphobia2_3ec)
31. Were you ever afraid that you might faint, lose control, or embarrass yourself in other ways? (pxt120202_agoraphobia2_fde)
32. Do you worry that you might be trapped without any way to escape? (pxt120202_agoraphobia2_ab8)
33. Do you worry that help might not be available if you needed it? (pxt120202_agoraphobia2_835)
34.How much did any of these fears ever interfere with your life or activities? (pxt120202_agoraphobia2_b1d)
Did you ever have a spell or an attack when all of a sudden you felt frightened, anxious, or very uneasy? (pxt120202_panic_attack)
Did any of these attacks occur when you were in a lifethreatening situation? (pxt120202_panic_during_life_threatening_situations)
Did any of these attacks occur when you were not in a lifethreatening situation? (pxt120202_panic_during_nonlife_threatening_situations)
About how many attacks have you had in your life? (pxt120202_panic_number_attacks)
How many months ago did you have the most recent attack? (pxt120202_panic_occurrence_most_recent_attack)
Did some of your attacks happen in a situation when you were not in danger or not the center of attention? (pxt120202_panic_occur_not_center_of_attention)

We already asked about specific situations that cause unreasonably strong fears (heights, elevators, snakes, etc.). When you have sudden anxiety attacks, do they usually occur in specific situations that cause you unreasonably strong fear? (pxt120202_panic_specific_situations)
Did you ever have an attack when you were not in a situation that usually causes you to have unreasonably strong fears? (pxt120202_panic_attack_random)
When you have attacks: Does your heart pound or race? (pxt120202_panic_heart_race)
When you have attacks: Do you have tightness, pain, or discomfort in your chest or stomach? (pxt120202_panic_chest_stomach_pain)
When you have attacks: Do you sweat? (pxt120202_panic_sweat)
When you have attacks: Do you tremble or shake? (pxt120202_panic_shake)
When you have attacks: Do you have hot flashes or chills? (pxt120202_panic_hot_flashes_chills)
When you have attacks: Do you, or things around you, seem unreal? (pxt120202_panic_things_seem_unreal)

Detailed scoring information can be found in the following pdf: Please see scoring information in the following pdf: "https://www.phenxtoolkit.org/toolkit_content/supplemental_info/psychiatric/additional_info/CIDI_SF_scoring.pdf" (scoring_instructions_120202)

module.longName: Part II: Symptom Assessment from the Symptom Check List 90

instruction.text: The Psychiatric Working Group recommends that investigators ask respondents questions 2, 11, 17, 23, 24, 33, 39, 57, 63, 67, 72, 74, 78, 80, 81, 86 from the Symptom Checklist 90. In the Symptom Checklist 90, the respondent rates symptoms that include nervousness, irritation, outbursts, and restlessness on a scale of 0 to 4 (with 0 = not at all, 1 = a little bit, 2 = moderately, 3 = quite a bit and 4 = extremely) which best describes how much that problem has bothered them in the last 4 weeks. Symptom Checklist90Revised (SCL90R). Copyright © 1975, 2004 Leonard R. Derogatis, Ph.D. Published and distributed exclusively by NCS Pearson, Inc. All rights reserved

module.preferredDefinition: Part II: Symptom Assessment from the Symptom Check List 90

question.questionText: The Psychiatric Working Group recommends that investigators ask respondents questions 2, 11, 17, 23, 24, 33, 39, 57, 63, 67, 72, 74, 78, 80, 81, 86 from the Symptom Checklist 90. In the Symptom Checklist 90, the respondent rates symptoms that include nervousness, irritation, outbursts, and restlessness on a scale of 0 to 4 (with 0 = not at all, 1 = a little bit, 2 = moderately, 3 = quite a bit and 4 = extremely) which best describes how much that problem has bothered them in the last 4 weeks. Symptom Checklist90Revised (SCL90R). Copyright © 1975, 2004 Leonard R. Derogatis, Ph.D. Published and distributed exclusively by NCS Pearson, Inc. All rights reserved (part2_instructions_0120202)

protocol.preferredDefinition: This protocol is divided into two separate parts. The first part contains the subsections of the Composite International Diagnostic Interview - Short Form (CIDI-SF) that screen for the presence or absence of generalized anxiety disorder, specific phobia, social phobia, agoraphobia and panic attack. The second part contains specific questions from the Symptom Check List 90 (SCL-90) that provide a more quantitative measure of anxiety symptom severity.

form.longName: PhenX PX120301 - Obsessive Compulsive Disorder Screener
form.preferredDefinition: This screening protocol includes the 15 interviewer-administered questions from the Obsessive Compulsive Disorders section (Section I) of the Composite International Diagnostic Interview - Short Form (CIDI-SF), developed for the World Health Organization.

question.questionText: Have you ever been bothered by having certain unpleasant thoughts of your own that kept entering your mind against your wishes? An example would be if you kept having the idea that your hands are dirty or have germs on them. (pxt120301_ocd_unpleasant_thoughts_germs)

Another example of an unpleasant thought would if you kept having the idea that you might harm someone, even though you really didn't want to. Or you might have had thoughts you were ashamed of, but couldn't keep out of your mind. Have you ever had any unpleasant and persistent thoughts like that? (pxt120301_ocd_thoughts_harm_ashamed)

Please think about the time in your life when some of these unpleasant thoughts were bothering you the most. Did some of these thoughts seem to you to be unreasonable? (pxt120301_ocd_thoughts_seem_unreasonable)

Please think about the time in your life when some of these unpleasant thoughts were bothering you the most. Did these thoughts keep coming back again and again into your mind no matter how hard you tried to resist, ignore, or get rid of them? (pxt120301_ocd_thoughts_keep_coming_back)

Please think about the time in your life when some of these unpleasant thoughts were bothering you the most. Did you ever tell a doctor about these thoughts? (pxt120301_ocd_tell_professional_about_thoughts)

Please think about the time in your life when some of these unpleasant thoughts were bothering you the most. Did thinking about these ideas interfere with your life or work, or cause you difficulty with your relatives or friends, or upset you a great deal? (pxt120301_ocd_thoughts_interfere_activities)

Some people have the unpleasant feeling that they have to do something over and over again even though they know it is foolish, but they can't resist doing it things like washing their hands again and again or going back several times to be sure they've locked a door or turned off the stove. Have you ever had to do something like that over and over? (pxt120301_ocd_repeat_actions)

Was there a time when you felt you had to do something in a certain order, like getting dressed perhaps, and had to start all over again if you did it in the wrong order? (pxt120301_ocd_certain_order)
Has there been a period of several weeks when you felt you had to count something, like the squares in a tile floor, and couldn't resist doing it even when you tried to? (pxt120301_ocd_counting)
Did you have a period when you had to say certain words over and over, either aloud or to yourself? (pxt120301_ocd_repeat_words)

Please think about the time in your life when having to do these things was bothering you the most (doing or counting or checking something over and over, or in the same order). Did you think that these actions were unnecessary or that you overdid it? (pxt120301_ocd_think_actions_unnecessary)

Please think about the time in your life when having to do these things was bothering you the most (doing or counting or checking something over and over, or in the same order). Did you tell a doctor about having to do these things? (pxt120301_ocd_tell_professional_about_actions)

Please think about the time in your life when having to do these things was bothering you the most (doing or counting or checking something over and over, or in the same order). Did having to do these things interfere with your life or work, or cause you difficulty with your relatives or friends, or upset you a great deal? (pxt120301_ocd_actions_interfere_activities)

protocol.preferredDefinition: This screening protocol includes the 15 interviewer-administered questions from the Obsessive Compulsive Disorders section (Section I) of the Composite International Diagnostic Interview - Short Form (CIDI-SF), developed for the World Health Organization.

form.longName: PhenX PX120901 - Symptoms Of Autism Spectrum Disorders Adult
form.preferredDefinition: The Autism Quotient for Adults is a 50 question self report instrument designed to screen age 16 and older for symptoms of autism. A scoring key is also included. This instrument comes from the UK where age 16 is more readily considered an adult.

module.longName: Symptoms of Autism Spectrum Disorders - Adult
module.preferredDefinition: Symptoms of Autism Spectrum Disorders - Adult

question.questionText: I prefer to do things with others rather than on my own. (prefer_do_things_with_others)
I prefer to do things the same way over and over again. (prefer_do_things_same_way)
If I try to imagine something, I find it very easy to create a picture in my mind. (easy_create_picture_imagination)
I frequently get so strongly absorbed in one thing that I lose sight of other things. (strongly_absorbed)
I often notice small sounds when others do not. (notice_small_sounds)
I usually notice car number plates or similar strings of information. (notice_license_plates)
Other people frequently tell me that what I've said is impolite, even though I think it is polite. (people_call_me_impolite)
When I'm reading a story, I can easily imagine what the characters might look like. (easily_imagine_story_characters)
I am fascinated by dates. (fascinated_dates)
In a social group, I can easily keep track of several different people's conversations. (keep_track_different_conversations)
I find social situations easy. (social_situations_easy)
I tend to notice details that others do not. (notice_details)
I would rather go to a library than a party. (library_over_party)
I find making up stories easy. (make_up_stories_easily)
I find myself drawn more strongly to people than to things. (drawn_to_people)
I tend to have very strong interests which I get upset about if I can't pursue. (strong_interests)
I enjoy social chitchat. (enjoy_chit_chat)
When I talk, it isn't always easy for others to get a word in edgeways. (dominate_conversation)
I am fascinated by numbers. (fascinated_by_numbers)
When I'm reading a story, I find it difficult to work out the characters' intentions. (difficulty_understanding_story_characters)
I don't particularly enjoy reading fiction. (does_not_enjoy_fiction)
I find it hard to make new friends. (difficulty_making_friends)
I notice patterns in things all the time. (notice_patterns)
I would rather go to the theatre than a museum. (theatre_over_museum)
It does not upset me if my daily routine is disturbed. (daily_routine)
I frequently find that I don't know how to keep a conversation going. (difficulty_with_conversation)
I find it easy to read between the lines" when someone is talking to me." (read_between_conversation_lines)
I usually concentrate more on the whole picture, rather than the small details. (whole_picture_over_details)
I am not very good at remembering phone numbers. (difficulty_remembering_phone_numbers)
I don't usually notice small changes in a situation, or a person's appearance. (notice_small_changes)
I know how to tell if someone listening to me is getting bored. (tell_if_boring_others)
I find it easy to do more than one thing at once. (easy_to_multitask)
When I talk on the phone, I'm not sure when it's my turn to speak. (difficulty_with_phone_conversations)
I enjoy doing things spontaneously. (enjoy_spontaneity)
I am often the last to understand the point of a joke. (difficulty_understanding_jokes)
I find it easy to work out what someone is thinking or feeling just by looking at their face. (easy_to_read_facial_expression)
If there is an interruption, I can switch back to what I was doing very quickly. (easy_to_switch_after_interruption)
I am good at social chitchat. (good_at_chitchat)
People often tell me that I keep going on and on about the same thing. (go_on_about_one_thing)
When I was young, I used to enjoy playing games involving pretending with other children. (pretend_with_other_children)
I like to collect information about categories of things (e.g. types of car, types of bird, types of train, types of plant, etc.). (collect_categories)
I find it difficult to imagine what it would be like to be someone else. (difficulty_imagining_being_someone_else)
I like to plan any activities I participate in carefully. (enjoy_planning_activities)
I enjoy social occasions. (enjoy_social_occasions)
I find it difficult to work out people's intentions. (difficulty_working_out_intentions)
New situations make me anxious. (anxious_new_situations)
I enjoy meeting new people. (enjoy_meeting_new_people)
I am a good diplomat. (good_diplomat)
I am not very good at remembering people's date of birth. (difficulty_remembering_birth_dates)
I find it very easy to play games with children that involve pretending. (easy_to_play_pretend_games)
See Scoring Key at https://www.phenxtoolkit.org/index.php?pageLink=browse.protocoldetails id=120901 (scoring_0120901)

protocol.longName: Symptoms of Autism Spectrum Disorders - Adult
protocol.preferredDefinition: The Autism Quotient for Adults is a 50 question self report instrument designed to screen age 16 and older for symptoms of autism. A scoring key is also included. This instrument comes from the UK where age 16 is more readily considered an adult.
